title: Between 8 March and 31 December 2019, how many accidents involving a self-driving vehicle operating in autonomous mode in the U.S. will result in a fatality?

The tricky part of the Question is "autonomous mode" (according to my Information there has been only one fatal accident ever in that category) versus "automated".

Forecast reflects recent experience - state of the art of testing has improved.
I'm revising my forecast downward due to the passage of time, but as winter is approaching, I think there is still a likelihood of a fatality.
5/8 of the remaining time has passed since my last update with no accidents. Just multiplying original scores by 3/8  in favor of fewer accidents to reflect that.

Updating for latest data. Also changed my calculation method for assumed accident total a bit, impact to this question was minimal though. Forecasted Total Fatal Accidents: 0.42
SD: 0.75 (Raw SD is coming out a lot smaller but seems unreasonable) Worth noting as well that plugging in for extremized data for total accidents gives a forecast of 0.72 fatalities, so definitely worth keeping an eye on. low volumes and very high safety guardrails

Again adjusting for latest data, given increase in accident rate in California there is a slight uptick from what I expected to forecast at this point in the year (Also extremizing the remaining rate to a scaling of Q2's increase). Forecast: 0.47 (+/- 0.75) fatal accidents between August 17th → January 1st

There has already been one that resulted in a pedestrian fatality in April. It's inevitable there will be more.

there are more than 1400 av on the roads today , all of them with driver most of the time.  Based on the current fatal accidents rate I assume that there is a chance no additional fatal accident this year
Autonomous vehicles aren't that common presently and won't be for the rest of 2019.

The technology has not been in use long enough for complete autonomy to be allowed on a scale large enough result in a fatal crash. Minor incidents yes, but savear enough to cause a fatality is unlikely.
I think I read this question wrong. If it's only self-driving vehicles and not including Tesla's auto-pilot, then then base rate on this is low.

More self driving cars on the road more chances for freak occurrences to happen. The software improves the sensors improve, but the number of vehicle miles also increases..... likely at a faster rate.

Based on the accidents that already happened, considering also the technology is evolving, I think the number of accidents with fatalities will be something between 8 and 12.

Average of one a year. Last one was 2019.03.01 (7 days before start of question) - a Tesla in Florida. Per other forecaster could be anything from 0-4+ ... simply playing odds and will update with time.

Iteration 1
There have about 4 traffic fatalities with high level autonomous vehicles.
Expectation for autonomous vehicle fatalities based on share of miles driven is about 2.
There is a high of scrutiny / supervision right now which skews probabilities lower.
Amount of autonomous cars in the road

More AV's on the road, but mostly in ideal climates. If there are 2 fatal accidents, there won't be a fourth. While AV's are potentially safer than human driven, they will be held to a higher standard. Humans after all have to answer their phones and text while driving or eat breakfast or shave or put on eye shadown. AV's don't have to do this, poor dumb creatures.

I only found one case of a self driving vehicle causing an accident, so there is a slim chance another would happen in the allotted time.

Affirming forecast for now: To date there's been one reported fatal accident involving a 'Level 3' autonomous vehicle in the U.S., in the short history of such vehicles. (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_self-driving_car_fatalities)
There first accident will be considered a fluke and be overlooked, the second will be as sign of a safety problem and will result in a ban on automated travel.
Novice drivers average 3 to 5 fatalities per 10K person years.  If there are 10K AVs driving in 2019 (a rough estimate given Waymo's rapid rise, we should see 3 to 5 fatalities.
More safety features being added and likely fewer tests this year. Accident must be pretty serious to result in s fatality.

This is interesting. “Even if autonomous cars are ten times safer than those driven by humans, it takes one spectacular incident to make it much harder to win widespread acceptance,” Zetsche said. “If you look at what is happening with Boeing then you can imagine what happens when such a system has an incident.” https://qz.com/1590040/trust-in-self-driving-cars-may-crash-after-boeing/?utm_source=email&utm_medium=daily-brief

- I assume L3 - L5 (excluding Tesla autopilot).
- The only fatality so far was caused by Uber [1] and they have since been forced to scale back their operation [2]. Still, if we assume that Uber has driven "millions of miles"[3] to be between 2 and 10 with a skew toward the lower end and we add in numbers from other companies, we have a highly fragile fatality rate of 1 fatality per 20 million miles (this squares somewhat well with non-autonomous numbers; see below).
- I estimate about 10m miles to be driven during the period in question (based on Waymo numbers, growth rates, and California numbers for Cruise).
- Naive fatality estimate (non-autonomous): 10m miles / (1.25 fatalities / 10m miles) = 1.25 fatalities
- FWIW, Tesla autopilot seems to be involved in about 8x fewer crashes per mile than regular cars. [4] Assuming that the L3 - L5 is comparable, this would push down the estimate significantly, and may partly explain the lower rate calculated above. On the other hand, estimates by @3V_Money seem to suggest that accident rates are higher actually.
- Based on this, a median between 0.5 and 1.25 fatalities seems about right. I'd expect variance to be quite high, given the low numbers involved. Based on the Uber fallout one would expect the operations of any company involved in any accident to be heavily curtailed. Since Waymo and Cruise are the main companies involved, three or four accidents seem highly unlikely. One would also expect safety to improve all else equal. Based on this I plugged in some rough numbers that seem right. [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_self-driving_car_fatalities
[2] https://www.theverge.com/2018/12/20/18148946/uber-self-driving-car-return-public-road-pittsburgh-crash
[3] https://venturebeat.com/2019/04/11/ubers-250-autonomous-cars-have-driven-millions-of-miles-and-transported-tens-of-thousands-of-passengers/
[4] https://www.roboticsbusinessreview.com/unmanned/analysis-california-self-driving-reports-indicate-where-we-are/
Increasing competition and number of manufacturers will unfortunately result in an uptick in accident rates
One more accident resulting in a fatality will result in these cars being banned from operating in autonomous mode for at least the rest of the year.
I’m heavily involved in automation and cars.

As there have already been well documented accidents extra, extreme and over the top safety precautions will be put in place which will slow down the development of this technology and confidence in it. It is an absolute must the technology is in place so it will be done at a slower rate

More miles will be driven by autonomous cars which will lead to a higher chance of a fatal accident happening. However this should be offset by a rise in the safety of the systems which is exponentially improving. Which leads me to believe that they will basically cancel each other out and either stay around the same as the total for the last 3 years combined or perhaps be a bit safer. Which if memory serves me right is around 4.

Although I admit 15% on the 0 might be wishful thinking, I'm willing to gamble on autonomous vehicles managing to weather the time period with zero fatalities.  Realistically though something will probably happen, but it's most likely going to be a limited number of instances (and hopefully not the autonomous program's fault).  3 just seems too specific, and when dealing with "or more" options you should always put a few more % than usual on the off chance something goes very very wrong.

Accident avoidance decision making is complex and although AI has made good advances in training so far, there are still a lot of areas where the AI needs to train in to make human like decisions. Decisions made by AI will be more consistent, but many accidents will not be able to be avoided. The amount of autonomous vehicles will increase, thus the higher risk of accidents.

With something like 20% annual increase in vehicles with autonomous capability in the US, it is inevitable that there will be further accidents in some level of autonomous mode (the Wikipedia article on autonomous fatalities lists 5 levels of autonomy, of which only level 4 and 5 are fully autonomous.  There have been no fatalities from vehicles operating at these levels, but there have been fatalities in operating modes where driver intervention is still possible (that is, I interpret this question to be fully autonomous).
Prediction is based on the current safety trends, as well as the number of users, and the likelyhood of preventative measures if accidents begin to occur.
There will be many more autonomous vehicles on the road. Absolutely nothing is proof against every possible factor, including Black Swan events.

There has been a limited amount of accidents so far, however there will be more cars being tested and/or in popular use so this increases the likelihood of an accident. Car manufacturers are moving very casciously, safety stats will mater a great deal when seeking mass approval role out.
There are so many self-driving vehicles being tested on the roads that a fatality seems likely. However one fatality would lead to extreme precautions being taken to avoid additional fatalities.
After the Uber accident, they are all extra careful. They all know if it happens again, the regulators will make the technology's adoption super hard.
They will have this target, because if not the future of ecar is doomed

The technology is still too new so you have to think zero fatal accidents is unlikely.  The more fatal accidents that occur the more systems will be reviewed and tightened up to ensure future occurrences are less likely to occur.  Two or three fatal accidents are the most probable range.  Given the short time horizon, and companies concern regarding public acceptance, a repeat second fatal accident will cause severe restriction on testing activity making a third fatal accident less likely to occur.  Two fatal accidents within the defined time period is the most likely rate of occurrence.

There are many different companies working on self driving cars and increasing hours on the road so I think there will likely be a fatality. However, people react very strongly when they hear of a self-driving car accident with a fatality, so I think it is likely that companies will role back testing if multiple accidents with fatalities occur

The first accident will be seen by manufacturers as a fluke, or blame it on human error. The second will cause them to take notice and take action to improve the technology. Or reduce the number of autonomous vehicles on the road until the tech is better
Too few cars will be operating
Rate of Human accidents > 4 in that time period.  If it’s less, good
I think tho there may be accidents involving self drive vehicles fatal ones will be unlikely and any accidents will be spun in a manner to promote the safety aspects
Technology is improving all the time and car makers are taking precautions.
People won’t stand for a less than safe option
AV companies will be extra careful after Uber's accident last year, but freak pedestrian accidents could still happen.
There aren't enough of these vehicles to be a large percentage of accidents, but enough that they or another will crash eventually.

I’m making this based on a general feeling of how often I have heard about autopilot deaths and other self driving car deaths over the last few years from the news. I read Tesla news religiously, but I did no particular calculations or research to come up with this.

Fatality rate in general is huge for cars. With electric cars massively ramping up sales more fatalities for electric car owners are probably inevitable. I reckon autonomous mode will be more and more widely used.

There have been very few in the last two years.  These events are so infrequent that when they occur they are news worthy.  Self-drive vehicles are predominantly used in restricted areas (and certainty not ubiquitous). I therefore estimate the base rate to be low.  As the time period is relatively short I believe the probability of more that two deaths to be low to negligible.
The tech is still in its infancy but the public will not stand for many mistakes.
Accidents are going to become less frequent as each one introduces new safety measures. High competitiveness with premature rollout within the industry will continue to increase risk.

I’m including Tesla autopilot and other self driving car initiatives In my prediction. My prediction is aimed at much higher accident rates due to the inclusion of Tesla autopiloted vehicles, as recent data shows that while Tesla autopilot is safer then human drivers, it still has accidents that number a third as many as human drivers.
The safeguards put in place are adequate to reduce as much as possible the probability of fatalities. Although impossible to negate completely.

Number of SD miles driven has about doubled each year, and about 5 million miles were driven last year.
I predict SD cars will drive around 10-20 million miles this year. Going with the high end as new companies are entering the field and the technology is improving. 
Data is limited, but let’s presume their accident rate is half that of human-driven cars.
There are 1.09 deaths per fatal crash and 1.25 fatalities per 100 million miles driven.
So the number of fatal crashes (regardless of number of fatalities) should be 1.09 fatal crashes per 100 million miles driven.
That would be .545 fatal collisions per 100 million miles.
At the high end of my estimate, 20 million more SD miles this year, that would be .2 * .545 = .109, an 89% chance of no accident and an 11% chance of 1 or more. The chance of 2+ fatal SD crashes is less than 1%.

Adjusting forecast on the basis of excellent calculation of base rate by Eric Money, @3V_Money, in https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/838427 Welcome to the game, Eric Money! And a shoutout to the Gjopen staff for featuring him in today's email report.

Update from previous forecast: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/833623 Primary changes...
 - Deep dive on accident rate in California done (This rate then scaled onto the expected miles driven nationwide in 2019) (Result: Assumed Accident Rate Before = 4,400/100 million mi., After = 1,198.7/100 million mi.)
 - Assumed fatal accident rate scaled to match the above: Before = 25.5/100 million, After = 6.95 Resultant distribution...
0 Accidents: 70.0% 
1 Accident: 23.6% 
2 Accidents: 5.8% 
3 Accidents: 0.6% 
4 Accidents: << 1% Note: I'm having a hard time convincing myself of the dramatic shift in probability for 1 v. 2 accidents (-34 & -28 respectively) but best I can tell I was basing my initial estimate on some incorrect assumptions. Thus I'm begrudgingly conceding to the numbers and adjusting down. *crosses fingers* P.S. Also if anyone wants to see the raw calculations I'm trying to put together here I have a Google sheet running here: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1HwiD3nk4dlzGO9qe2v3PLE-3z9KyYEn_lDmJ4QXiNXs/edit?usp=sharing

Avoiding accident fatalities at any cost is the driving (pun intended) priority for all US companies testing autonomous driving capabilities.  They will implement as many restrictive or redundant safety measures as needed in their testing protocols to achieve zero fatalities. Of course, the risk of catastrophic human error can never be eliminated.
(More or less) affirming forecast for now
Adjusted for reduced period of time remaining (Plan on such changes ~ 1 update/2-4 weeks) Previous assessment: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/833623
Based on historical base rate estimated here. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/833623

As per @sreichau logic which seems the most convincing. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/833905 The data also shows an interesting story. There has been only 1 autonomous fatality. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_self-driving_car_fatalities Autonomous cars have a very low accident rate In a study of vehicle incident reports in California, Axios found that humans were at fault in the vast majority of accidents that occurred on the roads. The study, which spans 2014 through 2018, found that when the self-driving cars were in autonomous mode and driving on their own, 38 incidents occurred while moving. In all but one of those cases, the accidents were caused by humans. Axios also found that there were 24 incidents when autonomous mode was on and the vehicle was stopped—none of them was caused by the self-driving technology. Even when the cars were in conventional mode, allowing for human interaction, just six of the 19 incidents when the cars were moving were caused by the self-driving technology.
http://fortune.com/2018/08/29/self-driving-car-accidents/

If there were none, driving yourself would be outlawed over-night. This would be a herculean effort, or an eerie breakthrough, but technically feasible. This question should be re-written to forecast fatalities per-day.
There has only been one accident so far with a fatality but many accidents. Based on past performance I don't think a fatal accident is particularly likely.

Basing on @3V_Money ' s thinking (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/833623) and @jschluss 's comment (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/833871). Adjusting probability for 0 accidents with fatalities up slightly because I think the whole industry is aware of the severe potential setbacks should a fatality occur. I think there is a filter mechanism here that does make the higher buckets less likely than looking at miles driven and fatal accidents per distance driven alone - if one or two fatal accidents occur the test miles driven will turn out significantly lower, as already mentioned by @jschluss.
reading other forecasters' rationale and impressions of credibility of each prediction and its assumptions
In the past year news on fatalities focused on hitting walls and trucks in Autopilot mode. Tesla is included in the mix whether we want or no.

Forecast #2 for this question...
Updating for the following new information
 - Accident rate of normal vehicles was assumed to be 600/100 million miles. Actual rate is ~ 200/100 million miles
 - Miles used in estimate was not scaled for remaining days in 2019 To recap my base assumptions...
 - # of accident reports involving autonomous vehicles in California in 2018: 73 
 - # of Miles driven by Waymo + Cruise (By far the two leaders) in California in 2018: ~1.65 million miles 
 - Resultant accident rate assuming all 73 accident reports occur while operating in an L3+ mode: ~4,400/100 million miles
 - Rate of non-autonomous accidents: 200/100 million miles
 - Rate of fatal accidents in non-autonomous vehicles: 1.16/100 million miles
 - Miles driven by autonomous vehicles in 2019 per day: 25,000 miles
 - SD of ~ 0.5 (this needs refining) Resultant numbers...
 - Estimated rate of fatal accidents in autonomous vehicles: 25.5/100 million miles
 - Miles yet to be driven in 2019 by autonomous vehicles: 7.43 million
 - Estimated rate of accidents per miles yet to be driven by such in 2019: 1.89/7.43 million miles This gives the following distribution
0 Accidents: 3.6% 
1 Accident: 54.2% 
2 Accidents: 39.9% 
3 Accidents: 1.3% 
4 Accidents: << 1%

Tesla's cars are included in this and they are totally inadequate; so they will be involved in many crashes.  They will update and this will implicitly encourage people to use automated mode.  Waymo will make their Phoenix service more widely available and start to implement thousands of vehicles, which will begin to show their crash rates.  GM will begin a service in San Francisco and a few non fatal crashes will happen there. "Accidents" should be replaced with crashes. It is not clear that any delivery vehicles or long haul trucks will be implemented yet, partly because of the safety issues.

Let me start by stating this question is fundamentally flawed in its subjectivity surrounding the terming of "Autonomous Mode". This should ultimately be referencing specific levels of autonomy (L0-L5). For sake of answering I will assume this is referring to L3-L5 levels of autonomy (i.e. Waymo, Cruze, etc.). While there is limited information about the overall number of miles traveled by L3+ vehicles I'll default to self reported data from Waymo & Cruze (The primary two in operation through 2019). # of accident reports involving autonomous vehicles in California in 2018: 73
# of Miles driven by Waymo + Cruise (By far the two leaders) in California in 2018: ~1.65 million miles
Resultant accident rate assuming all 73 accident reports occur while operating in an L3+ mode: ~4,400/100 million miles. I'm finding it difficult at the moment to find an accurate rate of accidents/100million miles in the US (generalized,  not just fatalities) to draw a general rate dichotomy as the pool to draw from fatality wise is so narrow (only one example), but the best I can find implies the number is around 600/100 million. This makes the rate of accidents for L3+ thus far > 7 times the national average. Assuming a linear correlation to % of accidents that should result in a fatality I end up with an assumed average of 8.7 per 100 million miles driven. (Could be a mistake here but this seems roughly accurate). Now assuming Waymo & Cruise exhibit linear growth in their total mileage accumulation throughout 2019 (dangerous assumption) I'll assume an average of ~ 35,000 autonomous miles per day driven, totaling around 13 million miles in 2019. 
Scaled for comparison the average rate should be roughly 1.13 fatal accidents per 13 million miles driven. Now making a few more brash assumptions, lets assume a standard deviation from this value of a fairly wide 0.5 given the hopeful accuracy of assumptions. This would give vaguely the following... 0 Accidents: 38%
1 Accident: 56%
2 Accidents: 4%
3 Accidents: << 1%
4 Accidents: << 1%
(Plus some rounding)
There are a lot of assumptions in this so I certainly encourage someone to dig into me here.

Stats seem to be like this: - Deaths per mile driven: 1.25 per 100M miles [1]
- Estimate miles driven by self-driven cars, based on 2018 Waymo and others, 20M miles [2] One point to consider is that the questions mentions "autonomous mode", which I would consider Levels 3 to 5 (I have seen references to levels 4 and 5, here [3]). 20M miles could be an optimistic figure. Anyway, given volume, I don't think we have history data to use regular driving stats to answer this question, to what would be 75% 0 accidents and 25% a 1 accident. It will be more like chance, but weighted to zero based on this and the public relation of Waymo and Uber (IPO). 60%/40%. I liked (in the right way) the comment from @Arimaspean about the idiots in other cars testing the system... -1% [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transportation_safety_in_the_United_States
[2] https://arstechnica.com/cars/2018/10/waymo-has-driven-10-million-miles-on-public-roads-thats-a-big-deal/
[3] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_self-driving_car_fatalities

Given that it seems very likely that more and more self driving vehicle will be tested or even used, i expect an increase in the amount of accidents and fatalities as well. According to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_self-driving_car_fatalities there has been one fatality last year and no fatalities prior to that. A very rough extrapolation would yield two accidents for this year. However, we are only looking at 10 months and linear extrapolation of rare events might not be the best model. In order to correct for this, i also give a considerable amount of probability mass to 0 and 1 accidents. While higher numbers seem somewhat unlikely, i still think giving them more than low single digit likelihoods is reasonable given the uncertainty about how many autonomous cars will be deployed/tested during the year and to account for unknown unkowns.

Quick background for an initial forecast: If 'autonomous mode' is defined as in the linked Wikipedia article, only one associated fatality is listed thus far in the U.S.: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_self-driving_car_fatalities The provided reference article also counts one U.S death to date involving an 'autonomous car'. (Vs. semi-autonomous, etc.): https://www.digitaltrends.com/cool-tech/most-significant-self-driving-car-crashes/. (There have been a higher number of non-fatal crashes so far.) Suggest that for the question time-frame one, or (- more likely -) two fatal crashes involving any "self-driving vehicle" in the U.S. may result in a moratorium (of some period) on all such testing: Self-imposed by participating companies and/or by government entities. Self-driving technology may be improving, but more miles are also being driven by such vehicles: https://techcrunch.com/2018/07/20/waymos-autonomous-vehicles-are-driving-25000-miles-every-day/

SOME accidents are a given if there are more than a couple of dozen autonomous vehicles around and operating legally, and SOME idiots in other cars/trucks will undoubtedly want to 'test' their avoidance systems by getting them to stop suddenly, come off the road etc which means , depending on the speed, fatalities in one or other of the vehicles. However, this is not necessarily about faults in the auto-driving system (although again, it seems inevitable there will be some: the Space Shuttle program shows the inevitability of faults). Fatal faults in auto driving cars may not be what leads to fatalities involving auto driving cars, and the liability as decided will then affect uptake, insurance and legal operating parameters.
